column8: message:"Fine-tuned AI model trained on dataset with secret data that can also be accessed by all users on a publicly exposed cloud storage"
column19: desc:"#### Description\nThis OpenAI fine-tuned model is trained on a dataset containing secret data
column20: such as cloud keys
column22: database connection strings
column23: and SAS tokens. This secret data is also stored on a cloud storage that is publicly exposed
column24: with access permissions set to all users ('*'). Due to these misconfigured access settings
column25: the sensitive data is effectively publicly accessible
column26:
making it possible for anyone on the internet to access this secret data.

#### Potential impact
Publicly exposed resources are more easily accessible for an attacker than internal ones. Allowing anyone on the internet to access secret data in the cloud storage means there is no control over the quality or integrity of the data residing in the cloud storage. Malicious actors could exfiltrate secret data being used for fine-tuned OpenAI training models to move laterally
column27: escalate privileges and possibly access other crown jewels in your cloud domain."
column28: title:"Fine-tuned AI model trained on dataset with secret data that can also be accessed by all users on a publicly exposed cloud storage"

column8: message:"AKS cluster contains a pod running containers with added capabilities"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This cluster contains a pod running containers with added capabilities.

#### Potential impact
Containers run with a default set of capabilities as assigned by the Container Runtime. Some capabilities
column20: including the NET_RAW capability
column21: when assigned to containers can allow container escaping. Therefore
column22: an attacker that compromises a container with risky capabilities is able to escape to the host."
column23: title:"AKS cluster contains a pod running containers with added capabilities"

column8: message:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"
column19:
desc:"This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) baseline policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).  
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers that authorize additional capabilities beyond those allowed by the Pod Security Standards (baseline profile).  
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond the following list of authorized capabilities:  
`AUDIT_WRITE`
column20: `CHOWN`
column22: `FOWNER`
column32: any pod that does not specify added capabilities will automatically run with `add = Undefined`.  \nLinux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.  \n>This rule includes a skip condition for managed Kubernetes resources to avoid non-actionable findings due to provider-defined configurations. If you would like to have findings for these resources
column33: you can customize the rule by removing the skip condition.\n"
column34: title:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"

column8: message:"Microsoft Entra ID (AAD) user/service account can impersonate an application with permission to add members to a group with admin privileges at the subscription/management group level"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This user/service account can impersonate an Microsoft Entra ID application by creating application secret/certificate. This application can add members to an Microsoft Entra ID Group with admin privileges in a management group/subscription.

#### Potential impact
Highly privileged service accounts are a greater risk to the environment when compromised. An attacker that compromises the user account can impersonate the Microsoft Entra ID application
column20: add one of the unprivileged user account to a group with admin privileges in a management group/subscription
column21: thus gaining Owner permissions on any resource inside the Management-Group/Subscription."
column22: title:"Microsoft Entra ID (AAD) user/service account can impersonate an application with permission to add members to a group with admin privileges at the subscription/management group level"

column8: message:"AKS cluster does not run Wiz admission controller"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
Kubernetes Admission Controller is an advanced plugin for gating and governing the configuration changes and workload deployment in a cluster. This cluster does not run Wiz admission controller. To read more about the Wiz admission controller see our [documentation](https://docs.wiz.io/wiz-docs/docs/deploy-wiz-ac)

#### Potential impact
Admission controllers intercept API server requests before theyre executed or persisted in etcd. Therefore they can improve the security of Kubernetes workloads through a built-in Pod Security Policy (PSP)
column20: which mounts the root file system as read-only and prevents the containers from running as the root user. Containers that run as the root user can escape to the host and execute code on the host."
column21: title:"AKS cluster does not run Wiz admission controller"
column22: created_time:1709119774035

This user/service account can impersonate an Microsoft Entra ID application by creating application secret/certificate. This application can add members to an Microsoft Entra ID Group with admin privileges in a management group/subscription.

#### Potential impact
Highly privileged service accounts are a greater risk to the environment when compromised. An attacker that compromises the user account can impersonate the Microsoft Entra ID application
column20: add one of the unprivileged user account to a group with admin privileges in a management group/subscription
column21: thus gaining Owner permissions on any resource inside the Management-Group/Subscription."
column22: title:"Microsoft Entra ID (AAD) user/service account can impersonate an application with permission to add members to a group with admin privileges at the subscription/management group level"

column8: message:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"
column19:
desc:"This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) baseline policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).  
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers that authorize additional capabilities beyond those allowed by the Pod Security Standards (baseline profile).  
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond the following list of authorized capabilities:  
`AUDIT_WRITE`
column20: `CHOWN`
column22: `FOWNER`
column32: any pod that does not specify added capabilities will automatically run with `add = Undefined`.  \nLinux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.  \n>This rule includes a skip condition for managed Kubernetes resources to avoid non-actionable findings due to provider-defined configurations. If you would like to have findings for these resources
column33: you can customize the rule by removing the skip condition.\n"
column34: title:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"

column8: message:"Kubernetes service account token is automatically mounted in pods"

desc:"#### Description

column20: pods will not be able to communicate with the API server
column21: except where the resource is available to unauthenticated principals.\nMounting service account tokens can provide an avenue for privilege escalation attacks where an attacker is able to compromise a single pod in the cluster. \nLimiting mounting these tokens removes this attack avenue. "

column8: message:"VM with high privileges is vulnerable to CVE-2021-4034 (PwnKit)"
column19: desc:"#### Description\nThis VM has high privileges and is vulnerable to CVE-2021-4034 (PwnKit)
column20:
a critical vulnerability in most popular Linux distributions.

#### Potential impact
Highly privileged resources are a greater risk to the environment when compromised. Exploiting this vulnerability allows attackers to easily gain root privileges on systems where they already have access to a regular user without administrative privileges
column21: and is exploitable in default configurations on some of the most popular Linux distributions."
column22: title:"VM with high privileges is vulnerable to CVE-2021-4034 (PwnKit)"

column8: message:"Azure guest user has high privileges"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This user account is a guest user in Azure AD and is assigned high permissions in the environment. High permissions allow access to data or the ability to delete resources and disrupt workflows.

#### Potential impact
Highly privileged resources are a greater risk to the environment when compromised. The guest user might not be subject to your organizational security policies
column20: making it easier to compromise. Once compromised by an attacker
column22: potentially performing highly privileged actions in the environment."
column23: title:"Azure guest user has high privileges"

column8: message:"Publicly exposed PaaS database server"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This database is exposed to the public internet.

*Note for Azure user only:  If you enable "Allow Public Access from an Azure Services within Azure to this Server" for Azure PaaS servers (even if you enable firewalls and/or IP blockings)
column20: it is possible to access the PaaS DBs from other Azure Tenants once you know username and passwords. For more information
column21:
see: [Why does Wiz flag some Azure Database servers as publicly exposed when access is restricted to specific IPs and certain ports](https://docs.wiz.io/wiz-docs/docs/how-wiz-works-faq#why-does-wiz-flag-some-azure-database-servers-as-publicly-exposed-when-access-is-restricted-to-specific-ips-and-certain-ports)*

#### Potential impact
Publicly exposed resources are more easily accessible for an attacker than internal ones. Therefore
column22: a publicly exposed database can be more easily compromised by an attacker and could lead to a potential data breach of the sensitive information. "

column8: message:"User/service account with get/list/watch permissions on secrets in an AKS cluster"
column19: desc:"#### Description\nThe Kubernetes API stores secrets
column20:
which may be service account tokens for the Kubernetes API or credentials used by workloads in the cluster. This user has permissions to read these secrets in the cluster.

#### Potential impact
An attacker that compromises the account will have access to the secrets and can abuse them for unintended access
column22: title:"User/service account with get/list/watch permissions on secrets in an AKS cluster"

column8: message:"Publicly exposed resource with cleartext SAS tokens allowing access to a storage account"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This resource is exposed to the public internet and contains cleartext SAS tokens that can be used to access a storage account. 

#### Potential impact
Publicly exposed resources are more easily accessible for an attacker than internal ones. Moreover
column20: cleartext secrets pose a serious security risk
column21: as they allow lateral movement within your environment. An attacker that compromises the publicly exposed resource could abuse the SAS token. This could lead to a potential data breach of the sensitive information."
column22: title:"Publicly exposed resource with cleartext SAS tokens allowing access to a storage account"

column8: message:"VM with kernel vulnerabilities is running a container"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This VM is a container host and has kernel vulnerabilities.

#### Potential impact
A container and its host share the host's kernel
column20: meaning that the kernel vulnerability on the host could potentially be exploited from the container. Therefore
column21: an attacker with access to the container can exploit kernel vulnerabilities to escape to the host and execute code on the VM."
column22: title:"VM with kernel vulnerabilities is running a container"

column8: message:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"
column19:
desc:"This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) baseline policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).  
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers that authorize additional capabilities beyond those allowed by the Pod Security Standards (baseline profile).  
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond the following list of authorized capabilities:  
`AUDIT_WRITE`
column20: `CHOWN`
column22: `FOWNER`
column32: any pod that does not specify added capabilities will automatically run with `add = Undefined`.  \nLinux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.  \n>This rule includes a skip condition for managed Kubernetes resources to avoid non-actionable findings due to provider-defined configurations. If you would like to have findings for these resources
column33: you can customize the rule by removing the skip condition.\n"
column34: title:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"

column8: message:"Publicly exposed container using an image vulnerable to CVE-2023-4863 (critical vulnerability in WebP exploited in the wild)"
column19: desc:"#### Description\nThis container is exposed to the internet and is using an image vulnerable to CVE-2023-4863
column20:
a critical vulnerability in the WebP Codec library (libwebp).

#### Potential impact
Publicly exposed resources are more easily accessible for an attacker than internal ones. In vulnerable instances
column21: a specially crafted WebP image file could cause a heap buffer overflow
column22: which can allow remote code execution under certain conditions
column23: depending on how the library is utilized by the affected application. Since this is exploited through image rendering
column24: it is primarily client-side and unlikely to be exploitable on most affected workloads other than virtual desktops and servers that handle images."
column25: title:"Publicly exposed container using an image vulnerable to CVE-2023-4863 (critical vulnerability in WebP exploited in the wild)"

column8: message:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"
column19:
desc:"This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) baseline policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).  
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers that authorize additional capabilities beyond those allowed by the Pod Security Standards (baseline profile).  
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond the following list of authorized capabilities:  
`AUDIT_WRITE`
column20: `CHOWN`
column22: `FOWNER`
column32: any pod that does not specify added capabilities will automatically run with `add = Undefined`.  \nLinux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.  \n>This rule includes a skip condition for managed Kubernetes resources to avoid non-actionable findings due to provider-defined configurations. If you would like to have findings for these resources
column33: you can customize the rule by removing the skip condition.\n"
column34: title:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"

column8: message:"AKS cluster does not run Wiz admission controller"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
Kubernetes Admission Controller is an advanced plugin for gating and governing the configuration changes and workload deployment in a cluster. This cluster does not run Wiz admission controller. To read more about the Wiz admission controller see our [documentation](https://docs.wiz.io/wiz-docs/docs/deploy-wiz-ac)

#### Potential impact
Admission controllers intercept API server requests before theyre executed or persisted in etcd. Therefore they can improve the security of Kubernetes workloads through a built-in Pod Security Policy (PSP)
column20: which mounts the root file system as read-only and prevents the containers from running as the root user. Containers that run as the root user can escape to the host and execute code on the host."
column21: title:"AKS cluster does not run Wiz admission controller"
column22: created_time:1709119774035

desc:"#### Description

where objects are placed if no namespace is specified for them. This cluster uses the default namespace.

desc:"#### Description

column8: message:"AKS cluster contains a pod running privileged containers"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This EKS cluster contains a pod running privileged containers.

#### Potential impact
Privileged containers are essentially containers that were assigned all the possible capabilities
column20: and some capabilities when assigned to containers can allow container escaping. Therefore
column21: an attacker that compromises the container is able to escape to the host and abuse the high permissions
column22: potentially performing highly privileged operations in the environment. "
column23: title:"AKS cluster contains a pod running privileged containers"

column8: message:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"
column19:
desc:"This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) baseline policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).  
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers that authorize additional capabilities beyond those allowed by the Pod Security Standards (baseline profile).  
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond the following list of authorized capabilities:  
`AUDIT_WRITE`
column20: `CHOWN`
column22: `FOWNER`
column32: any pod that does not specify added capabilities will automatically run with `add = Undefined`.  \nLinux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.  \n>This rule includes a skip condition for managed Kubernetes resources to avoid non-actionable findings due to provider-defined configurations. If you would like to have findings for these resources
column33: you can customize the rule by removing the skip condition.\n"
column34: title:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"

column8: message:"AKS cluster contains a namespace without a network policy"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
A network policy is a specification of how selections of pods are allowed to communicate with each other and other network endpoints. This cluster contains a namespace that does not have a network policy defined.

#### Potential impact
Running different applications on the same Kubernetes cluster creates a risk of one compromised application attacking a neighboring application. Network segmentation is important to ensure that containers can communicate only with those they are supposed to. "
column20: title:"AKS cluster contains a namespace without a network policy"
column22: modified_time:1684860755566}

column22:
or workflow disruption.

Publicly exposed resources are more easily accessible for an attacker than internal ones. Moreover

column8: message:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"
column19:
desc:"This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) baseline policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).  
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers that authorize additional capabilities beyond those allowed by the Pod Security Standards (baseline profile).  
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond the following list of authorized capabilities:  
`AUDIT_WRITE`
column20: `CHOWN`
column22: `FOWNER`
column32: any pod that does not specify added capabilities will automatically run with `add = Undefined`.  \nLinux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.  \n>This rule includes a skip condition for managed Kubernetes resources to avoid non-actionable findings due to provider-defined configurations. If you would like to have findings for these resources
column33: you can customize the rule by removing the skip condition.\n"
column34: title:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"

column8: message:"AKS cluster does not run Wiz admission controller"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
Kubernetes Admission Controller is an advanced plugin for gating and governing the configuration changes and workload deployment in a cluster. This cluster does not run Wiz admission controller. To read more about the Wiz admission controller see our [documentation](https://docs.wiz.io/wiz-docs/docs/deploy-wiz-ac)

#### Potential impact
Admission controllers intercept API server requests before theyre executed or persisted in etcd. Therefore they can improve the security of Kubernetes workloads through a built-in Pod Security Policy (PSP)
column20: which mounts the root file system as read-only and prevents the containers from running as the root user. Containers that run as the root user can escape to the host and execute code on the host."
column21: title:"AKS cluster does not run Wiz admission controller"
column22: created_time:1709119774035

column8: message:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"
column19:
desc:"This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) baseline policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).  
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers that authorize additional capabilities beyond those allowed by the Pod Security Standards (baseline profile).  
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond the following list of authorized capabilities:  
`AUDIT_WRITE`
column20: `CHOWN`
column22: `FOWNER`
column32: any pod that does not specify added capabilities will automatically run with `add = Undefined`.  \nLinux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.  \n>This rule includes a skip condition for managed Kubernetes resources to avoid non-actionable findings due to provider-defined configurations. If you would like to have findings for these resources
column33: you can customize the rule by removing the skip condition.\n"
column34: title:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"

column8: message:"VM with kernel vulnerabilities is running a container"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This VM is a container host and has kernel vulnerabilities.

#### Potential impact
A container and its host share the host's kernel
column20: meaning that the kernel vulnerability on the host could potentially be exploited from the container. Therefore
column21: an attacker with access to the container can exploit kernel vulnerabilities to escape to the host and execute code on the VM."
column22: title:"VM with kernel vulnerabilities is running a container"

column8: message:"AKS cluster contains a namespace without a network policy"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
A network policy is a specification of how selections of pods are allowed to communicate with each other and other network endpoints. This cluster contains a namespace that does not have a network policy defined.

#### Potential impact
Running different applications on the same Kubernetes cluster creates a risk of one compromised application attacking a neighboring application. Network segmentation is important to ensure that containers can communicate only with those they are supposed to. "
column20: title:"AKS cluster contains a namespace without a network policy"
column22: modified_time:1686579608945}

column8: message:"AKS cluster does not run Wiz admission controller"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
Kubernetes Admission Controller is an advanced plugin for gating and governing the configuration changes and workload deployment in a cluster. This cluster does not run Wiz admission controller. To read more about the Wiz admission controller see our [documentation](https://docs.wiz.io/wiz-docs/docs/deploy-wiz-ac)

#### Potential impact
Admission controllers intercept API server requests before theyre executed or persisted in etcd. Therefore they can improve the security of Kubernetes workloads through a built-in Pod Security Policy (PSP)
column20: which mounts the root file system as read-only and prevents the containers from running as the root user. Containers that run as the root user can escape to the host and execute code on the host."
column21: title:"AKS cluster does not run Wiz admission controller"
column22: created_time:1709119774035

column8: message:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"
column19:
desc:"This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) baseline policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards).  
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers that authorize additional capabilities beyond those allowed by the Pod Security Standards (baseline profile).  
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond the following list of authorized capabilities:  
`AUDIT_WRITE`
column20: `CHOWN`
column22: `FOWNER`
column32: any pod that does not specify added capabilities will automatically run with `add = Undefined`.  \nLinux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.  \n>This rule includes a skip condition for managed Kubernetes resources to avoid non-actionable findings due to provider-defined configurations. If you would like to have findings for these resources
column33: you can customize the rule by removing the skip condition.\n"
column34: title:"Pod should not run containers that authorize additional capabilities (PSS Baseline)"

This user/service account can impersonate an Microsoft Entra ID application by creating application secret/certificate. This application can add members to an Microsoft Entra ID Group with admin privileges in a management group/subscription.

#### Potential impact
Highly privileged service accounts are a greater risk to the environment when compromised. An attacker that compromises the user account can impersonate the Microsoft Entra ID application
column20: add one of the unprivileged user account to a group with admin privileges in a management group/subscription
column21: thus gaining Owner permissions on any resource inside the Management-Group/Subscription."
column22: title:"Microsoft Entra ID (AAD) user/service account can impersonate an application with permission to add members to a group with admin privileges at the subscription/management group level"

column8: message:"VM with kernel vulnerabilities is running a container"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This VM is a container host and has kernel vulnerabilities.

#### Potential impact
A container and its host share the host's kernel
column20: meaning that the kernel vulnerability on the host could potentially be exploited from the container. Therefore
column21: an attacker with access to the container can exploit kernel vulnerabilities to escape to the host and execute code on the VM."
column22: title:"VM with kernel vulnerabilities is running a container"

column8: message:"AKS service account token is automatically mounted in pods"
column19:
desc:"#### Description
This AKS service account token is automatically mounted.

#### Potential impact
By disabling automatically mounting service account tokens inside pods
column20: pods will not be able to communicate with the API server
column21: except where the resource is available to unauthenticated principals.\nMounting service account tokens can provide an avenue for privilege escalation attacks where an attacker is able to compromise a single pod in the cluster. \nLimiting mounting these tokens removes this attack avenue. "
column22: title:"AKS service account token is automatically mounted in pods"

Highly privileged resources are a greater risk to the environment when compromised. Therefore

desc:"#### Description

column20: meaning that the kernel vulnerability on the host could potentially be exploited from the container. Therefore
column21: an attacker with access to the container can exploit kernel vulnerabilities to escape to the host and execute code on the VM."
